title: A New Restaurant
question_text: The manager of a new restaurant wishes to know if there is local interest in the cuisine his restaurant offers prior to signing a contract in Foodtown, NY. He obtains a complete list of all residents of Foodtown and decides to select a simple random sample of $150$ residents. He will send sample menus and an invitation for a complimentary lunch to the $150$ residents randomly chosen. What is the likelihood that all $150$ randomly chosen residents will live in the same neighborhood?

choices.text: Zero. By taking a simple random sample, the manager is ensuring the residents selected will be spread out throughout Foodtown, NY.
The same as for any group of $150$ residents in all of Foodtown, NY.
Very unlikely as each neighborhood could be considered a cluster and in a cluster sample, each cluster is unlikely to be chosen.
Very likely. A simple random sample ensures each group of $150$ residents is very likely to be chosen as the final sample.
